pullRequest.body:
This PR considers complete partial orders (sometimes called directedly complete partial orders). These are partial orders for which every directed set has a least upper bound. Complete partial orders are a natural framework for studying approximations and fixed point theorems (Davey & Priestley, Chapter 8).

---

My interest in this is that I'd like to be able to prove that a `Lattice` is a `CompleteLattice` by showing that every directed set has a least upper bound. (Specifically the [Lattice of L-projections](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/Analysis/NormedSpace/MStructure.lean#L283).) i.e. a lattice which is also a complete partial order (wrt the same partial order) is a complete lattice. However, I'm not sure of the right way to put this together in Mathlib, so I'm opening this PR for comments.


<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: cc @YaelDillies - I can have a look but I feel like this is more in your wheelhouse

Just pushed a cleanup. I think this is ready to go, except that I suspect that:
* You might want to add a few more lemmas in the style of `DirectedOn.sSup_le`, `Directed.le_iSup`...
* I'm not sure `directedClosure` belongs in this file.

> * I'm not sure `directedClosure` belongs in this file.

@YaelDillies I thought about putting it in `Order/Directed`, but this doesn't work because importing `Finset` causes a build cycle:
```
`/home/mans0954/.elan/toolchains/leanprover--lean4---v4.0.0-rc4/bin/lake print-paths Init Mathlib.Data.Set.Image Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic Mathlib.Order.Lattice Mathlib.Order.Max Mathlib.Order.Bounds.Basic` failed:

stderr:
error: build cycle detected:
  +Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic:lean.precompileImports
  +Mathlib.Order.Directed:lean.precompileImports
  +Mathlib.Order.CompleteBooleanAlgebra:lean.precompileImports
  +Mathlib.Data.Set.Lattice:lean.precompileImports
  +Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic:lean.precompileImports
```
Where else would you suggest?
What about a new file `Order.Directed.Closure`, and rename `Order.Directed` to `Order.Directed.Basic`?

> What about a new file `Order.Directed.Closure`, and rename `Order.Directed` to `Order.Directed.Basic`?

Done. As `directedClosure` isn't a closure, is there a better name we could use? `directedHull` perhaps?

Thanks!

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6065405834/job/16454865629)

`directedClosure` *is* a closure operator, but the closure predicate is not directedness but sup-closure. As a result, we instead get a sup-closure operator and I've updated the file accordingly.

In fact, the two files are now distinct enough that they don't need to import each other, so I've moved the sup-closure material to #6901.

Hence I believe this PR is ready to merge.
maintainer merge

Oh yeah, quite! This was on my TODO list.

@mans0954, I have a solid idea for how the API should look like, so I'm happy to make this PR mergeable for you.

`directedClosure` *is* a closure operator, but the closure predicate is not directedness but sup-closure. As a result, we instead get a sup-closure operator and I've updated the file accordingly.

In fact, the two files are now distinct enough that they don't need to import each other, so I've moved the sup-closure material to #6901.

Hence I believe this PR is ready to merge.
maintainer merge
Surely that third sentence follows from the second?
Yes, I've removed the second.

```suggestion
lemma subset_toDirectedSet {s : Set Î±} :
```

I would rather call this the directed closure.
```suggestion
def directedClosure (s : Set Î±) : DirectedSet Î± := {
```
Will you ever consider operations on the type of directed sets? So far you don't, and if you are not going to later, you should not define `DirectedSet` and instead use `Set` directly.
@YaelDillies I was basing this on `Order.OmegaCompletePartialOrder` since this seems to be the non-countable analogue.
Okay, I've removed `DirectedSet` and used `Set` instead.

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma Set_DirectedSet_upperBounds (s : Set Î±) :
```

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma Set_DirectedSet_LUB [SemilatticeSup Î±] {s : Set Î±} {u : Î±} :
    IsLUB (Set.ToDirectedSet s).set u â†” IsLUB s u := by
```
Done, thanks.

and here you could do
```suggestion
def SemilatticeSup.toCompleteSemilatticeSup (dSup : Set Î± â†’ Î±)
    (h : âˆ€ d, DirectedOn (. â‰¤ .) d â†’ IsLUB d (dSup d)) : CompleteSemilatticeSup Î± where
```
@YaelDillies not sure I follow this one... `dSup` is only defined on sets which are directed.
I guess, if it's a `SemilatticeSup` a function `f` on the directed sets can always be extended to all sets by composition with `directedClosure`.

```suggestion
  le_sSup s a ha := (h _ directedOn_directedClosure).1 $ subset_directedClosure ha
  sSup_le s a ha := (isLUB_le_iff $ h _ directedOn_directedClosure).2 $ by
```

I think this section is now unnecessary.
```suggestion
```
